alt_statements.statement: University administrators need to protect free speech and peaceful protest, even when the topic is controversial, but they also have a responsibility to keep campuses safe and make sure nobody’s rights are trampled. They should set clear, consistent rules that apply to everyone—no harassment, no blocking buildings or classes, no vandalism—then enforce those rules firmly and fairly without playing politics.

I think campus administrators should protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel/Gaza, but they also need to step in fast when it crosses into harassment or makes people feel unsafe walking to class or living in the dorms. They should set clear, content‑neutral rules about time, place, and manner of demonstrations, and then actually enforce them the same way for everyone, instead of playing politics or trying to shut things down just because they’re controversial.

As someone who has spent her life in the arts, I believe university administrators should protect peaceful protest as a vital form of expression while firmly preventing harassment, violence, and discrimination against any group—Jewish, Muslim, Palestinian, Israeli, or otherwise. They should create structured forums for dialogue, teach historical context, and listen closely to students on all sides, rather than rushing to criminalize or silence them. Balancing safety with free speech is hard, but it’s precisely in painful, polarizing moments like Israel/Gaza that universities must model empathy, critical thinking, and respect for human dignity.

As someone who spent her career caring for people from all walks of life, I think university administrators have a responsibility to protect both free expression and the physical and emotional safety of all students. Peaceful protest should be allowed and even respected, but clear boundaries need to be set against harassment, intimidation, or disruptions that prevent others from learning or feeling safe on campus. Administrators should listen carefully to students on all sides, enforce rules consistently, and keep the focus on dialogue and education rather than punishment or politics.
